concern: Up until this past weekend, I lived on campus with my girlfriend and a couple of roommates.  Unfortunately, one of my roommates died in her bedroom over the weekend.  She was an older student with a bunch of health issues, and had temporarily died/had serious medical emergencies many times in the apartment previously.  These situations got to be so stressful that me, my girlfriend, and our other roommate have been going to therapy appointments on campus to try and process everything, and I fell behind on my classes. The other roommates and I had raised concerns to the housing department about living with her, the stress we were under being in this situation, and feeling like we were medically responsible for her.  The college said we were not responsible for her, but their actions and things they’ve said behind our backs say otherwise.  For example, my roommate who passed away and my girlfriend were relocated to temporary housing before finals due to a pipe burst; the roommate later told me and my girlfriend that the assistant director of housing called her and asked if anyone was staying with her that night, as she (assistant director) was uncomfortable with her living someplace by herself (my girlfriend had decided to not stay in the temporary housing). Roommate’s husband was staying with her that night on a visit, which was satisfactory to the assistant director.  The college as a whole had told us multiple times prior to our roommate dying that they were working on a solution, but nothing happened until after she died. When she was alive, we were only asked once to provide input about what we wanted to have happen and were told in that meeting it was best for her to stay living with us because if they moved her to a different apartment she would traumatize more students.  Housing also said they were uncomfortable moving the rest of us to different apartments because then our roommate would be alone and no one would be able to call for medical assistance if she needed it, and that they couldn’t kick her out of housing just because she had health issues.  After months of getting run around by housing and other departments, my roommate died in the apartment, and the school hasn’t done anything to help the rest of us deal with the past few months beyond telling us sorry that she died, telling us that counseling exists, and moving me and my girlfriend into a new apartment.  I’m very frustrated that I was put into and forced to stay in this situation for as long as I was. Surely there were things the college could have done to let my roommate stay living on campus while making sure she was staying safe (letting her have a care attendant or having her live with an RA are two options that come to mind).  My parents are saying legal action is warranted in this situation and that I should try and get the school to reimburse my housing costs for the year, but I wanted to get some input from others before I decide what I’m going to do.  Is there anything I can or should reasonably ask my college to do to make up for me being kept this situation?  Is legal action necessary?

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! Whats on your mind today?
I'm feeling overwhelmed by the stress from my recent living situation and its impact on my well-being. I'm here to process these emotions and explore ways to move forward.

It sounds like you're dealing with a lot right now. It's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. It takes courage to reach out and talk about these emotions. Would you like to share more about your living situation?

Yes, I'd like to share more about how the stressful living situation affected my daily life and mental health. I'm hoping to gain some strategies to cope with the lingering frustration and move forward.

Absolutely, I'm here to listen and help you find ways to cope with the stress and frustration you're feeling. It's important to acknowledge the impact that your living situation has had on your daily life and mental health. Can you tell me more about the specific ways in which the stress from your living situation has affected you?

The stress from my living situation has made it difficult to focus on my studies and has left me feeling constantly anxious and emotionally drained. I'm seeking practical ways to manage this frustration and regain a sense of stability in my daily life.

It's clear that the stress from your living situation has been a significant challenge for you, and it's great that you're seeking ways to cope with these emotions. In order to manage the frustration and regain stability, let's explore some potential strategies together. What are some activities or practices that have helped you feel more grounded or relaxed in the past?

In the past, going for runs and spending time outdoors has helped me feel more grounded and less overwhelmed. Journaling my thoughts has also been a useful practice for releasing some of that built-up frustration and anxiety.

It's great to hear that you've found some activities that have helped you in the past, such as running, spending time outdoors, and journaling. These are all excellent strategies to manage stress and improve mental well-being. Considering your past experiences, which of these activities would you like to prioritize and incorporate into your daily routine to help you cope with your current challenges?

I think prioritizing running and spending time outdoors would be best for me right now, as they help clear my mind and reduce the constant anxiety I've been feeling. I'd also like to incorporate journaling into my daily routine to better process and release the built-up frustration from my situation.

It's great that you've identified running, spending time outdoors, and journaling as the strategies you'd like to prioritize. To help you get started, let's create an actionable plan for incorporating these activities into your daily routine. Would you prefer setting aside specific times for each activity, or would you rather integrate them more flexibly throughout your day?

I would prefer setting aside specific times for each activity to help me maintain consistency and better manage my stress. Integrating them flexibly could work on some days, but a structured approach feels more reliable for keeping my anxiety in check.

That's a great approach! Let's start by scheduling your running sessions. Would you prefer setting aside time in the morning to start your day energized or in the evening to unwind after a stressful day?

I would prefer setting aside time in the morning for my running sessions to help energize my day and keep my anxiety under control. This structured start feels like a reliable way to build consistency into my routine.

It's wonderful that you've chosen to prioritize running in the morning to help manage your stress. To maintain consistency, it might be helpful to set a specific time each morning, such as 700 AM. Additionally, consider scheduling regular journaling and outdoor time in your daily routine. Remember, these strategies will support your well-being and help you regain stability. Let's plan to check in again in two weeks to discuss your progress and make any necessary adjustments.

I appreciate the suggestions for structuring my routine with running at 700 AM and adding journaling and outdoor time to manage my ongoing stress from the roommate situation. I'll plan to check in again in two weeks as discussed.
Great, I'm glad we have a plan in place! Remember to be kind to yourself and stay consistent with your new routine. I look forward to hearing about your progress in two weeks. Until then, take care!
Thanks for the encouragementI'll focus on staying consistent with my routine to manage the stress from this situation. Take care until we talk again in two weeks.
